# Importing all necessary libraries.
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
source.5c4ccfef:
# Loading the data.
from sklearn.datasets import load_boston
X, y = load_boston(return_X_y=True)
source.e32d5631:
# Implementing the Linear Regression model.
from sklearn import linear_model
reg = linear_model.LinearRegression()
source.cc702c05:
# Splitting the data into training and testing sets.
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size = 0.2, random_state = 1)
source.08362c71:
# Printing out the predicted values.
y_pred = reg.predict(X_test)
print(y_pred)
source.79e29dc3:
# Printing out the actual values.
print(y_test)
source.8cd101e5:
# Printing out how well the model performed.
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error
print(mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred))
source.8872ee1f: In this notebook I take a look at the very simple linear regression algorithm to predict house prices in the city of Boston.
